text.p: These are some of the leading stories in the Jordanian press on Tuesday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- Moslem Brotherhood says government asks for immediate talks without preconditions on Brotherhood's plans to boycott November parliamentary elections.
- Allenby Bridge opened for people entering and leaving West Bank, but not for those trying to get to Gaza.
- Cabinet to discuss alterations to civil service regulations to extend periods of unpaid leave available to state employees.
- Hamas sounds warning of Palestinian infighting if Palestinian Authority cracks down on it.
- Shares on Amman stock exchange lost 67 million dinars ($94 million) in June.
- Transport and Communications Minister Bassam al-Saket says state-owned Royal Jordanian airlines still has 41.4 million dinar deficit in 1997.
- Moslem Brotherhood members register to vote in parliamentary elections.
- Philadelphia Bank raises capital by 5.5 million dinars. Saudi Prince Waleed bin Talal takes one million shares worth 1.1 dinars each, Khalifah bin Abdul-Mohsen al-Seif takes another million.
- Japan's Grant Assistance for Grass Roots Projects has donated $2.1 million to Jordan in the past two years.
